comments.content:
If you haven’t already been through it, _Grid Systems in Graphic Design_ by Josef Müller-Brockmann is probably the best historical source you’ll find—a great piece of high modernism.

_Making and Breaking the Grid_ by Timothy Samara is a decent book about Grids in practice, and has a few bits of history in there as well. Maybe not the best book research though, it’s more of a guided tour for brainstorming ideas. Still, with full color and bleeds, it’s pretty amazing that this can be had at under $20. There’s plenty more also, I’m sure you’ll get plenty of good input.

Good luck!
The Grid by Allen Hurlburt - 1978 - Van Nostrand Reinhold Company, NY

thanks for your help -much appreciated

been through grid systems but i shall be checking out the other 2 ASAP

regards

Making and Breaking the Grid: A Graphic Design Layout Workshop

[http://www.amazon.com/Making-Breaking-Grid-Graphic-Workshop/dp/156496893...](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828233747/http:/www.amazon.com/Making-Breaking-Grid-Graphic-Workshop/dp/1564968936 "http://www.amazon.com/Making-Breaking-Grid-Graphic-Workshop/dp/1564968936")

I think many designers work out systematic approaches but don’t share so much beyond the fundamentals. It has all changed a bit with digital type as well—not being bound to the point system so tightly.

You’ve got to keep a little for yourself, and this is so clearly a part of design where you can differentiate yourself.
